awd_abstract_narration:
LaShanda Korley, Jonathan Pokorski, Gary Wnek (Case Western Reserve University), Stuart Rowan (University of Chicago)

Materials that are found in Nature display a wide range of properties including responsiveness to the environment, signal transmission, and the ability to adapt to support life. Learning from Nature or biomimicry can be a powerful tool in designing, developing and accessing the next generation of synthetic materials and systems. Furthermore, biomimetic concepts will account for an estimated $1.2 trillion in global economic development, and have already contributed to familiar products like Velcro and wind turbines. Thus, there is a critical need for the US to educate the next generation of internationally-minded biomimicry thinkers to develop a new wave of innovative materials. As such, this PIRE brings together an interdisciplinary team of US and Swiss collaborators to carry out research and education in the area of Bio-Inspired Materials & Systems. Specifically, the PIRE will utilize inspiration from Nature to design new materials that can change toughness in response to their environment, are safer and more effective biological implants, will transmit nerve-like electrical signals, and can respond to the environment to initiate biological processes, all for use in soft robotic applications. 

A range of innovative educational and outreach activities will train US students in learning from Nature and in a bio-inspired philosophy. This training will happen in an international context with Swiss collaborators, world leaders in biomimetic concepts and research. Students will gain exposure to themes cutting across chemistry, polymers, physics, biology, and engineering in the development of multi-functional, active materials. Mentoring, diversity, cultural competency, globalization, and effective scientific communication are emphasized as critical elements of the PIRE.

Nature has a multitude of examples of complex materials and systems that go well beyond the current capabilities of synthetic systems. The innovation potential in this domain is vast and a large-scale interdisciplinary effort is required to realize paradigm-changing scientific breakthroughs. To that end, an international partnership between biomimicry experts at Case Western Reserve University (CWRU), the University of Chicago (UoC), and the University of Fribourg/Adolphe Merkle Institute in Switzerland in Bio-inspired Materials and Systems is established. Building upon collaborative strengths in polymer synthesis, computational modeling, mechanical characterization, robotics, imaging, manufacturing, biology, biomedical engineering, physics, and molecular engineering, five Bio-inspired Materials and Systems projects are envisioned: (1) Silk-inspired Nanocomposites: Spider/Caddisfly Silk Mimics; (2) Sea Cucumber, Squid Beak and Pine Cone Inspired Adaptive Composites; (3) Excitable Polyelectrolyte Fiber Networks/Gels: Toward Artificial Neurons; (4) Dynamic and Functional Fibers Inspired by the Extracellular Matrix; and (5) Soft Robotics Inspired by Worm Locomotion. These research thrusts are directed toward the development of functional, programmable, and responsive materials for deployment in soft robotic systems.  Faculty, graduate, and undergraduate students will spend time in Switzerland engaging in synergistic research/educational activities. An educational and innovation partnership with local thought leaders in biomimicry will guide the training of the next-generation of global scientists and engineers in this interdisciplinary endeavor. Effective science communication will be highlighted via existing programming with the Museum of Science and Industry (MSI) of Chicago. Community outreach activities include research opportunities at CWRU and UoC for underrepresented high school students in STEM as part of an expanded Biomimetic Envoys program and the development of biomimetic hands-on demonstrations for annual participation in the Martin Luther King Jr. (MLK) Discovery Day at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Nature has a multitude of examples of complex materials and systems that go well beyond the current capabilities of synthetic systems. The innovation potential in this domain is vast and a large-scale interdisciplinary effort is required to realize paradigm-changing scientific breakthroughs. To that end, an international partnership between biomimicry experts at the University of Delaware (UD), Case Western Reserve University (CWRU), the University of Chicago (UoC), University of California, San Diego (UCSD), and the University of Fribourg/Adolphe Merkle Institute in Switzerland in Bio-inspired Materials and Systems was established. Building upon collaborative strengths in polymer synthesis, computational modeling, mechanical characterization, robotics, imaging, manufacturing, biology, biomedical engineering, physics, and molecular engineering, five Bio-inspired Materials and Systems projects were investigated: (Thrust 1) Silk-inspired Nanocomposites: Spider/Caddisfly Silk Mimics; (Thrust 2) Sea Cucumber, Squid Beak and Pine Cone Inspired Adaptive Composites; (Thrust 3) Excitable Polyelectrolyte Fiber Networks/Gels: Toward Artificial Neurons; (Thrust 4) Dynamic and Functional Fibers Inspired by the Extracellular Matrix; and (Thrust 5) Soft Robotics Inspired by Worm Locomotion. These research thrusts were directed toward the development of functional, programmable, and responsive materials for deployment in soft robotic systems. Overall, this international research partnership made significant advances in the development of nature-inspired soft materials that exhibit mechanical adaptability, environmental responsiveness, tunable locomotion, and transient dynamics. These bio-inspired material innovations enabled the realization of all-soft robotic systems with complex performance and showcased the translation of biomimetic principles for functional materials design.

 

Intellectual Merit

Materials that are found in Nature display a wide range of properties including responsiveness to the environment, signal transmission, and the ability to adapt to support life. The PIRE: Bio-inspired Materials and Systems employed a biomimetic framework to develop a new generation of multi-functional, active materials, that impacted areas ranging from human health to sustainable engineering, enabled by an international collaboration of scientists and engineers with a breadth of skills and experience in a variety of disciplines. Several classes of responsive, soft materials were developed including water-triggered actuators and amphiphilic conetworks inspired by the molecular mechanisms of spider silk (Thrust 1); mechanically-adaptive and patternable polymers guided by the behavior of sea cucumbers and squid beaks for use as intracortical implants (Thrust 2); excitable neuron-like fibers and networks towards the realization of signal transduction in collapsible fibrous hydrogels and soft hydrogel batteries (Thrust 3); and mimicry of the extracellular matrix via hierarchical manufacturing of coextruded, degradable fiber mats with antibacterial potential (Thrust 4). Thrust 5 leveraged extensive computational modeling and robotic design technology to utilize high-thermal-expansion bilayer elastomers in the development of a mechanically-compliant, soft robot capable of worm-like locomotion.  Altogether, these innovations were enabled by the integration of experimental and computational expertise in polymer chemistry, physics, and manufacturing; biophysics; mechanical engineering; and biomedical sciences.    

 

Broader Impacts

Beyond the scientific advances in designing, developing, and accessing the next generation of synthetic materials and systems via bio-inspiration, the major findings from this project were disseminated in peer-reviewed journals/juried conference paper (~50); translated to intellectual property filings (~5); communicated via oral and poster presentations at conferences, workshops, and industrial visits; and utilized in the development of education and outreach activities. Fifteen faculty members, thirty-five graduate students, twenty-eight undergraduates, and five postdoctoral associates were engaged in the collaborative and international research, education, and outreach activities with the Swiss team at the University of Fribourg. Graduate and postdoctoral trainees were exposed to effective science communication and professional development via workshops and programming, including engagement with the Museum of Science and Industry (MSI) of Chicago, a virtual academic and industry speaker series, and modules on entrepreneurship and innovation. A key feature of this project was the graduate student research exchange program between the U.S. and Swiss teams, enabling cross-fertilization of relevant expertise, broader awareness of global diversity, and sustained collaboration.  Additionally, center-wide, community outreach activities were conducted, including hands-on, biomimetic demonstrations at the Martin Luther King Jr. (MLK) Discovery Day at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History, IME Molecular Engineering Fair (UofC), Inspiretist Event and Serviam Academy Enrichment Program (UD), and virtual biomimetic activities offered during the COVID-19 pandemic. A new graduate course on Bio-inspired Materials and Systems also was developed with materials accessible across all partner institutions. These robust activities have stimulated sustained partnerships across center participants with direct impact on career development, expanded research areas and technology development, and frameworks for effective training, mentoring, and outreach.

 


Last Modified: 01/15/2025
Modified by: Lashanda T Korley

Building upon collaborative strengths in polymer synthesis, computational modeling, mechanical characterization, robotics, imaging, manufacturing, biology, biomedical engineering, physics, and molecular engineering, five Bio-inspired Materials and Systems projects were investigated: (Thrust 1) Silk-inspired Nanocomposites: Spider/Caddisfly Silk Mimics; (Thrust 2) Sea Cucumber, Squid Beak and Pine Cone Inspired Adaptive Composites; (Thrust 3) Excitable Polyelectrolyte Fiber Networks/Gels: Toward Artificial Neurons; (Thrust 4) Dynamic and Functional Fibers Inspired by the Extracellular Matrix; and (Thrust 5) Soft Robotics Inspired by Worm Locomotion.These research thrusts were directed toward the development of functional, programmable, and responsive materials for deployment in soft robotic systems.
